section.title: Overview
section.text: Biodiesel fuel is made by chemically altering a vegetable oil or animal fat to reduce the viscosity, or the thickness, of the fluid to allow it to run in a regular diesel engine. This presentation explains the basic steps of producing biodiesel from start to finish.

section.title: Prepare oil
section.text: Though you can make biodiesel from virgin vegetable oils or animal fats, most homebrewers make biodiesel from used oils such as used cooking oil. Non-oil particles and water must be filtered out before moving the oil into the vessel where the oil will be made into biodiesel.

section.title: Heat oil
section.text: Heating the vegetable oil to around 120ÂºF will speed up the reaction, reducing the time needed for the reaction to complete from between four and eight hours to one or two hours.

section.title: The chemical process
section.text: Oil and fat are made up of fatty acids and glycerol, a viscous alcohol. In the process known as transesterification, another alcohol, typically methanol, is introduced to the oil. The glycerol breaks away from the fatty acids, and the fatty acids bond with the new alcohol to form biodiesel. Potassium hydroxide is frequently used as a catalyst, which means that it increases the rate of the reaction, but is not used up in the reaction. While the reaction can technically occur without a catalyst, the amount of heat and excess alcohol needed make it impractical to perform the transesterification without one.

section.title: Test for free fatty acids
section.text: Before starting the transesterification on a large batch of oil, a titration is performed. Titration is a test that indicates the amount of free fatty acids in waste oil. Free fatty acids will react with the methoxide during transesterification, reducing the amount of oil that gets made into biodiesel, so a titration will help determine how much extra catalyst is needed to ensure a more complete reaction.

section.title: Make methoxide
section.text: After titrating to determine how much catalyst is needed, the potassium hydroxide is mixed with the methanol to make methoxide. Potassium hydroxide is a crystalline solid, but will gradually dissolve in the methanol. This generally takes about 15 minutes.

section.title: Mix methoxide into oil
section.text: After the oil has been heated and the methoxide mixed, it is time to introduce the methoxide into the oil. This is usually achieved by spraying methoxide slowly into the reaction tank as the oil is being mixed constantly to help spread the reaction throughout the tank. Introducing the methoxide slowly helps the methoxide to react fully with the oil. During this phase, transesterification is taking place, and biodiesel and glycerol are being created. The reaction should be complete after one to two hours, leaving a mixture of biodiesel and glycerol in the reactor.

section.title: Let biodiesel separate from glycerol
section.text: After the reaction is complete, the biodiesel and glycerol are left in the reactor tank to separate and settle. Glycerol will sink to the bottom of the tank while the biodiesel floats on top. The tank should be left alone for eight or more hours to allow for the separation.

section.title: Drain glycerol
section.text: To remove the glycerol from the biodiesel, a valve at the bottom of the reaction tank is opened and the glycerol is drained out. Glycerol is cloudy in appearance and biodiesel is translucent, so the draining liquid is monitored for the change from cloudy to translucent, indicating that all of the glycerol has been removed. The glycerol can be disposed of, but can also be used to make soap.

section.title: Wash biodiesel
section.text: Biodiesel is washed to remove unreacted oil, free fatty acids and the leftover methoxide. There are a number of techniques for washing biodiesel, but the two most common are bubble washing and misting. In a misting wash, water is sprayed on top of the biodiesel and collects the impurities as it sinks. Bubble washing involves adding water to the biodiesel and creating air bubbles that push the water up through the biodiesel, then letting it sink to catch more impurities. Washing is usually done multiple times and can take up to 16 hours.

section.title: Remove wash water
section.text: After washing the fuel, the next step is to remove the water from the fuel. While water will naturally separate from biodiesel and most of the water can simply be drained out after separation, some water will still be suspended in the biodiesel. This water can be removed through evaporation encouraged by contact with air. Spraying the biodiesel itself will put more water in contact with air, encouraging evaporation.

section.title: The results
section.text: The biodiesel is now finished and ready to be loaded in a vehicle with a diesel engine. Commercial biodiesel is always mixed into petrodiesel, and is often sold in a mixture of 20% biodiesel to 80% petrodiesel, known as B20 biodiesel. Biodiesel homebrewers often run their diesel engines on pure biodiesel, or B100, especially in warmer climates, though in cold winter weather, biodiesel should mixed with petroleum diesel to ensure the fuel does not thicken into a gel in the fuel lines.
